title: How can we say that science is part of philosophy? - Quora

response.answer_text: To help you better grasp the reality here, let's rephrase the question. “Is there any philosophy in science” ? Obviously, yes! The reality is that all fields of knowledge whatsoever are dependent on philosophy including all of Science. Philosopy is essentially a metaphysical enterprise of theoretics. All fields of knowledge whatsoever are rooted and founded on metaphysical axioms or foundational principles which are the necessary prerequisites in order to have any said field of knowledge. For example, try putting the empirical method of science under a microscope to observe it. Now this obviously isn't possible because the empirical method itself is a metaphysical theory of determining how the natural world works via observation, experimentation and prediction based on the above. Ultimately, Philosopy and Science are connected at the hip even though Philosopy is the Mother of all knowledge in general. There is way to much to go into here, but you will never find two professionals who will agree on everything within their own respective fields of knowledge regardless of what fields you look. And this is because there is no escape from the metaphysics of belief or theory in any realm of thought or fields of knowledge whatsoever. For every layer of the universal onion that Man pulls back in discovery ten new layers spring up with even more philosophical questions with each new discovery. Truth and Reality are always waiting for Man over the next horizon and the next horizon after that perpetually. It's a perpetual game of hide and seek. No matter what Man discovers in any realm of thought or fields of knowledge, he cannot escape from further metaphysical speculations simply because you cannot exhaust or outstrip the theoretics in any realm of thought or field of knowledge. All knowledge evolves over time but we never come to the absolute Truth of things because knowledge itself is the eternal science of Metaphysics. There is much more to this but you would do well to contemplate it for yourself.

Philosophy used to cover areas that science now dominates. As science advances, philosophy retreats. Yet whatever is left for philosophers to speculate about, they have to accept science in the now non-philosophical areas. Philosophy still discusses God’s existence, but in doing so respects scientific theories. Philosophers also discuss Maxwell’s Demon, solipcism and whether other minds exist. They come close to contemplating their navel. Descartes would sit in bed and contemplate a wax candle melting, thinking deep thoughts. Socrates was certain of only thing, that he was uncertain of everything. Descartes was only certain that he thinks therefore he exists. Continental philosophy is about “big” questions, like existentialism. American philosophy is more into logical minutia, and largely irrelevant theories, to just about anyone. Einstein said God doesn’t roll dice, as if that was his philosophical response to quantum physics. We learned he was wrong. Oddly, he never received a Nobel for his relativity. Someone asked him what would he do if experiments showed relativity wrong. He responded the evidence doesn’t matter as he knows he’s right. Still, he predicted gravity waves, and a century later, they are no where to be seen. gravity is still a mystery in so far as it’s a force that can’t be unified with other forces. It acts at a distance, seemingly instantaneously, beyond the speed of light. It’s these types of empirical problems that leave the philosophers room to inject their speculation and philosophizing. quantum physics is the most confirmed theory short of the 2nd law of thermodynamics, yet it contradicts Einstein’s relativity. The macro & micro don’t jive. Hugh Everett, argued the multiple universe theory of quantum physics, that we go on living in a parallel universe after our biological death in our current universe. That leaves endless room for philosophy, at least in Europe. American philosophers are so empirical, they won’t speculate about really big questions. Is nothing something? Big philosophy question at a symposium couple years ago. Physicists weighed in too though. What is empirical about the absence of anything empirical?

Mathematics is called the “Queen of the Sciences.” Well, what do you say we dub philosophy the “King of the Sciences”? There’s enough justification for that bold step. These days we spurn Socrates and Plato. Aristotle… well, not really respectable science, we feel, but he did get the ball rolling. I say, “Wait a minute; aren’t we bad students?” Actually Aristotle is considered a poor student of his mentor Plato, who was a pure idealist, and Aristotle less so. Plato told the famous “Allegory of the Cave”, teaching in parable about the Scientific Method, with his “upward path” (identifiable as induction) and “downward path” (deduction no doubt). I am a physicist in the line of the quest of the Unified Field Theory. What we find is that the solution is not forthcoming unless we acknowledge and include the metaphysical realm in our model of reality and in our equations. So we’ve done it. In other words, at the end of this Great Circle of history, over 2,000 years, we find ourselves back where we started from, but having a much better foundation to finally appreciate it for what it is really telling us. What is the quantum wave, really? How is time regulated so precisely? What is this elusive “consciousness” after all? Of what are dreams made? Socrates, the great Sage, preached to his death to seek inwardly, where we shall find the answers to all things. Anamnesis he called it: recollection. Yes, coming around at last to our great and original Teacher: Philosophy is indeed the King of the Sciences!

In ancient Greece, particularly, the city-nation state of Athens, the Greeks attempted to find answers to the nature of the universe, the problem of truth, and the meaning and purpose of life. The magnitude of their philosophical accomplishment through investigation, experience in which rationality and logic were applied to acquire whatever irreducible minimum of faulty knowledge, self-conceited pretension were eliminated. During Socrates’ days the practice of what we call today as the “Socratic irony” which is profession of ignorance while questioning another in order to arrived at the truth. Plato’s Socrates had claimed in his Apology that he was the wisest of Athens, not because he was so incredibly wise, but because his fellow Athenians were so stupid, especially those who claimed they knew what in fact they did not know, while Socrates was the only one who acknowledge to himself that he knew nothing. And Socrates accused of impiety and corrupting the youth Athens, argued that he was the city’s greatest benefactor and deserving of its highest honors. After all, what Socrates had claimed of was perfectly true. He had taken pleasure in humiliating Athens reputed and conceited men before the crowd that gathered in the Agora, often by using clever debater’s tricks. He had a wicked sense of humor and found this to be very funny. Those he bested certain did not. The dimension of the ancient Greek philosopher both, the pre-Socratic and the post Socratic philosophical accomplishment is attested by the fact that philosophy ever since has been largely a debate over the validity of their conclusions, to paraphrase Nietzsche through his Twilight of the Idols, section 18.

Philosophers of physics, of biology, of psychology, of neuroscience and various other are obvious cases of philosophy and science being deeply intertwined. But philosophers in many fields take account of science in their philosophical work. (For instance: in philosophy of art, scientific work on perception sometimes shoes up.) And of course back in the day, the nascent version of what we now call science wad called natural philosophy.

No, I ask you: what type of philosophy is science? All science was originally called natural philosophy, once a subset of philosophy. This dates back to the ancient Greeks, when all of what Aristotle attempted was subsumed under the name philosophy. This includes his work both in physics and in biology. Philosophy is thus not a science, even though originally all natural science was philosophy. It would take until the remarkable Scientific Revolution of luminaries such as Galileo and Newton for science to begin to come into its own independent of philosophy.

Here is my thinking on this topic, off hand: Philosophy is the systematic, evidence based, (therefore scientific), study of cognition, a broad title for the operations of the human mind . I would contrast Philosophy with Neurology - the scientific study of the human brain. While operations of the brain are clearly physical and organic, operations of the human mind can be seen as emergent from the progressive social networking of many brains.

Yes, lots. There’s philosophy of physics, of biology, of scientific method in general; there’s philosophy of cognitive science; there’s philosophy of maths and logic; there’s philosophy of language and linguistics. All of these sub-fields draw heavily on scientific results. Philosophy isn’t just science, and some of it is really quite independent of science, but there’s certainly a lot of science used and discussed in philosophy. Quine had a nice phrase: philosophy is continuous with science. Where science stops and philosophy starts isn’t always obvious!

Science was a branch in philosophy until about 1832. That was the approximate time when it became the custom to refer to the research of natural phenomena as “science” and to abandon the original name “Natural Philosophy.

Philosophy is not a Science. It makes no predictions and does not rely on objective evidence. It is an analytic and evaluative subject akin to Fine Arts or Literature. For a definition of Science, read The Fundamental Difference between Religion and Science.

Philosophy may be called the "science of sciences" probably in the sense that it is, in effect, the self-awareness of the sciences and the source from which all the sciences draw their world-view and methodological principles, which in the course of centuries have been honed down into concise forms.

Philosophy used to be recognized as the Queen of sciences, but science has been redefined as Methodological Naturalism, meaning it treats of material things only. And now Philosophy consists in concepts alone. So in the sense of doing experiments, that is no longer within the pervue of modern science.
